results.title: Myst (MAC)
results.brief_description: You are about to be drawn into an amazing alternative reality. ‘Myst’ is a game that was designed from the ground up to draw you in with little or no distractions on the screen to interfere with the feeling of being there. It is non-linear, with the most depth, detail and reality you’ve ever experienced in a game. The key to playing the game is to lose yourself in this fantastic virtual exploration, and act and react as if you were really there.

results.title: Myself When Fourteen
results.creator_credit: Arthur Cantrill, Corinne Cantrill and Ivor Cantrill
results.brief_description: Brightly coloured animated drawings rotoscoped from high contrast black and white negative film of Ivor Cantrill aged 14, are integrated with the original negative and positive images on an optical printer to create patterns of black, white and colour. The film-maker reminisces about being 14 and describes the rotoscoping process. Ivor Cantrill is autistic, and his attention to detail and his preoccupation with repetition are positive aspects of his condition.

holdings.name: MOV file H264; ACMI Digital Access Copy - presentation

results.title: Myra Hess
results.brief_description: Dame Myra Hess plays the first movement of Beethoven’s Sonata in F Minor, Opus 57, (Apassionata). Close-ups show the technique of this artist, whose finest quality as a pianist is her sincerity and who was the inspiration of lunchtime concerts during the war in the National Gallery, London.

results.title: Myra (K)
results.creator_credit: Bosustow Entertainment, Nick Bosustow and Sam Weiss
results.brief_description: When Myra goes to dancing class she leaps, sways and kicks, just as Mrs. Page tells her to. But her enthusiasm and imagination go far beyond Mrs. Page.

results.title: My world: water
results.creator_credit: Churchill Films, Chevron Chemical Co and Paul Fillinger
results.brief_description: A montage of experiences related to the uses and delights of water. Explores the water cycle, importance of water to life, how water gets to our homes, the uses of water and the need for conservation. Uses songs, children’s voices and imaginative photography to highlight importance of water to us. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.

results.title: My wife, my horse and myself
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “A History of British art”.
The traditional 18th century style, portraits of dogs, horses and family was the province of British artists; their aristocratic clients bought their ‘real art’ in Italy. Written and presented by Andrew Graham-Dixon.

group_siblings.title: Dreams and hammers
group_siblings.creator_credit: BBC, Paul Tickell and Tanya Seghatchian

results.title: My way home
results.brief_description: This final part of Bill Douglas’ trilogy takes Jamie through adolescence into adulthood, from a children’s home to the RAF in Egypt. A brief return to his father’s home, where his ideas of attending art school are rebuffed by his stepmother, is followed by various menial jobs, until his conscription into the RAF, where he is befriended by Robert, who introduces him to art and literature and friendship. A subjective epilogue returns to Newcastle, but now the images are bleached out, as if the pain has been washed away, and we are left with the triumphant concluding image of a tree in full bloom.

results.title: My way
results.creator_credit: La Trobe University and Patricia Edgar
results.brief_description: This film contrasts and compares the attitudes and styles of three Victorian Education Department teachers. Controversial issues are discussed openly and classroom activities provide an inside view of teaching styles.
